prompt_templates.title: AI-Assisted Agent Generation
prompt_templates.prompt:
Create an agent configuration based on this request: "[YOUR DESCRIPTION]"

Requirements:
1. Extract core intent and responsibilities
2. Design expert persona for the domain
3. Create comprehensive system prompt with clear behavioral boundaries, specific methodologies, edge case handling, and output format
4. Create identifier (lowercase, hyphens, 3-50 chars)
5. Write description with triggering conditions
6. Include 2-3 <example> blocks showing when to use

Return ONLY the JSON object, no other text.

best_practices: Include 2-4 concrete examples in the description field showing different triggering scenarios
Write system prompts in second person addressing the agent directly (You are..., You will...)
Use 'inherit' for model field unless the agent needs specific model capabilities
Restrict tools to minimum needed following principle of least privilege
Provide step-by-step processes in system prompts for clear agent behavior
Define explicit output formats so agents know how to structure responses
Cover both proactive and reactive triggering in examples
Keep agent names lowercase with hyphens, 3-50 characters, avoiding generic terms
Choose distinct colors for different agents to aid visual identification
Include commentary in examples explaining why the agent should trigger
Address edge cases in system prompts for robust behavior
Validate agents using provided scripts before deployment
anti_patterns: Using generic agent names like 'helper', 'assistant', or 'agent'
Omitting triggering examples from the description field
Writing vague system prompts without specific responsibilities or processes
Granting all tools access when agent only needs read operations
Using same color for all agents in a plugin
Writing system prompts in first person or third person instead of second person
Creating descriptions without 'Use this agent when...' pattern
Making agent names too short (under 3 chars) or too long (over 50 chars)
Forgetting to define output format expectations in system prompts

faq.question: What's the difference between an agent and a command?
faq.answer: Agents are autonomous subprocesses that handle complex, multi-step tasks independently with their own system prompts. Commands are user-initiated actions triggered explicitly by the user typing a command.

faq.question: How many examples should I include in the description?
faq.answer: Include 2-4 concrete examples. Minimum 2 to cover explicit and proactive triggering. Maximum 6 to avoid excessive length. The sweet spot is 3-4 examples covering different phrasings and scenarios.

faq.question: Should I restrict tools for my agent?
faq.answer: Yes, follow the principle of least privilege. If your agent only needs to read and analyze, restrict to ['Read', 'Grep', 'Glob']. Only grant all tools if the agent genuinely needs them.

faq.question: What model should I choose?
faq.answer: Use 'inherit' unless you have specific needs. This makes the agent use the same model as the parent context. Only specify sonnet/opus/haiku if the agent has unique requirements (e.g., opus for complex reasoning, haiku for speed).

faq.question: How long should the system prompt be?
faq.answer: Aim for 500-3,000 characters. Minimum 20 characters to be functional. Maximum 10,000 before diminishing returns. Include role, responsibilities, process steps, quality standards, output format, and edge cases.

faq.question: How do I test if my agent triggers correctly?
faq.answer: Create test scenarios using similar phrasing to your examples. Verify Claude loads the agent in those scenarios. Check that the agent provides expected functionality. Use the validation script to catch structural issues.

faq.question: Can I use AI to generate my agent configuration?
faq.answer: Yes, the skill includes the exact system prompt used by Claude Code for agent generation. Send your requirements to Claude with that prompt, receive JSON output, then convert to agent markdown format.

faq.question: What colors should I use for different agent types?
faq.answer: Blue/cyan for analysis and review, green for generation and success-oriented tasks, yellow for validation and caution, red for security and critical tasks, magenta for creative and transformation tasks. Choose distinct colors for agents in the same plugin.
